Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reconstructing How Ecosystems Develop in High Northern Latitudes Using Genetic Markers and Temperature Signals in Lake Sediments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will reconstruct the plant community of a lake catchment over the last 7,000 years in order to better understand how tundra ecosystems respond to changing environmental conditions. As the Arctic warms and vegetation ranges are expected to expand northward; the increase in woody vegetation at high latitudes has important implications for both global and northern latitude ecosystems. By identifying how past plant community shifted and by reconstructing temperatures using two new techniques that analyze lake sediments, the doctoral student will enhance understanding about the complexities of the interplay between climate and biogeography at high latitudes both in the past and in a potentially warmer future. The project will provide research education and training opportunities for undergraduate students. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising doctoral student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student will use a combination of relatively new techniques to analyze past environments. One is the analysis of previously dated lake sediments for sedimentary ancient DNA, the complex mixture of degraded DNA found within bulk sediment, in order to identify the plants that lived within the lake catchment during the Holocene Epoch. The second technique the student will employ is a recently developed biochemical tool, the use of a distribution of a class of bacterial cell membrane lipids called "branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers" (brGDGTs) which is able to estimate past temperature. Using these techniques, the student will seek answers to the following sets of research questions: 1) Following the retreat of glaciers, how long did it take for dwarf shrubs to become established in the lake catchment? 2) How did plant diversity respond to the warmth of the early Holocene and cooling during the Late Holocene? 3) When did Betula (dwarf birch), a shrub that likes warmer temperatures currently near its northern limit in this field area, become established, and did it remain present through Holocene temperature fluctuations? Through the use of these new techniques in combination, the project's results will offer new perspectives about the climatic and temporal factors influencing northward plant migration in high northern latitudes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The greening of the Arctic is an observable effect of climate change, already resulting in ecological shifts and global-scale climate feedbacks. Records of past Arctic shrub migration, particularly following glacier retreat, can provide insight into how greening may proceed in a warming world. We combined emerging molecular techniques to produce a 7,000-year history of a tundra ecosystem against the backdrop of a local temperature record in a lake sediment core from southern Baffin Island, Arctic Canada. Sedimentary ancient DNA, the complex mixture of degraded DNA in lake sediment sourced from organisms living in and around a lake through time, is a relatively new tool for identifying changes in the local plant community over thousands of years. DNA analyses from the lake sediment core revealed the precise colonization timing for dwarf birch at 5,900 years ago, which was ~3,000 years after the site deglaciated and >1,000 years after other woody shrubs like willow had become established on the landscape. Bacterial cell membrane lipids that are sensitive to temperature change served as a paleotemperature indicator in the same sediment core. The warmest temperatures were earliest in the record, with marked cooling in the centuries preceding 6,000 years ago. Thus, colonization of a temperature-sensitive shrub (dwarf birch) lagged peak Holocene temperatures—a surprising finding given previous work that suggests climate is the primary limiting factor in shrub migration. This result suggests that inefficient dispersal, particularly to remote Arctic landmasses, may be a more important limitation on shrub migration for some species.

This work also highlights a key advantage of sedimentary ancient DNA over traditional paleoecological techniques, including pollen analysis in lake sediment. Nearby pollen records previously suggested the continuous Holocene presence of dwarf birch, which is likely a result of far-travelled wind-blown pollen introducing an exotic bias into these records. Our results confirm other recent research indicating the DNA is sourced very locally from within a lake catchment, making it a more precise tool for identifying colonization events. The false positives that can result from pollen-based records have major consequences for temperature reconstructions and studies of past vegetation dynamics using this common technique. Our study represents the first combination of an ancient DNA-based vegetation record with a lipid biomarker temperature record and underscores the potential of these molecular techniques used in tandem for Quaternary studies.

The results of this study were shared broadly with both the scientific community and the broader public. Co-PI Crump produced a short film with Orijin Media highlighting Arctic fieldwork and an overview of the research in accessible language. An engaging account of Arctic fieldwork was also made available to a wider audience via a first-person essay Crump wrote for publication in Scientific American online. Crump also collaborated with an artist at CU Boulder to create a visual narrative of the paleoclimate and paleoenvironmental record from this work via a multi-panel block print, which is currently on display in two venues around campus. In addition, the PIs developed a partnership with Arctic College of Nunavut (Iqaluit, Baffin Island) and shared their research with the predominantly indigenous students as guest instructors at their spring field camp. Finally, this research built important bridges between the paleoclimate and molecular biology communities, advancing techniques at the frontier of Quaternary paleoecology.
